Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Improving Access to Primary Care through E-Visits: Theory and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
E-visits, an alternative to the traditional office visit for medical services made possible by secure patient-physician communication, has the potential to improve access to care, and increase provider efficiency and patient satisfaction. For clinics that adopt e-visit strategy, several operational challenges arise. For example, how to determine the optimal staffing levels, how to allocate providers' time across different types of visits, how to schedule both office and e-visit requests, and how to identify system bottlenecks. An understanding of these operational dynamics can help in the identification of implementable mitigation strategies. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research project will be informed by collaboration with the Dean Health System and validated by utilizing Dean Health as a test case. The successful completion of this work will provide rigorous quantitative tools for primary care practitioners and administrators to improve patient access and quality of care.

If successful, the results of this research will provide mathematical model to study the complex primary care delivery process with e-visits as part of a mix of services offered by comprehensive health systems such as Dean Health. Based on analytical investigation of the stochastic processes underlying primary care operations, network analyses will be used to model the patient flow and clinic operations. The research team will begin with analyses of patient flow at the clinic level and then analyze work flow within an office visit. By addressing their interactions and considering the limited availability and multiple tasks of providers through recursive algorithms, researchers will investigate optimal staffing, resource allocation, and workflow scheduling problems. Bottleneck analysis will be performed to identify significant constraints and to develop strategies to mitigate them.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research is to establish an analytical framework by developing quantitative methods for analysis, design, and continuous improvement of primary care operations with e-visits (patient physician communication through patient portal) and apply the results in SSM Health Dean Medical Group.

Specifically, during the course of this project, we have developed analytical models to evaluate the efficacy of primary care operations with or without e-visits, such as patient length of stay, waiting time, staff utilization, and their variabilities, investigate and compare different workflow scheduling policies to design care operations in the most efficient manner, study patient portal data to predict potential risk and use it for care intervention planning, identify the bottlenecks or barriers in clinic operations and discover mitigation strategies which can lead to the largest improvement in system performance, and finally collect data to validate the model and apply the recommendations in SSM Health Dean Medical Group in Madison, WI. Moreover, a new course on stochastic modeling in healthcare delivery systems has been developed, within which the results from this project have been introduced. The graduate students supported by this project have received substantial exposure to theoretical challenges and practical activities, which can enhance their understanding of healthcare systems and their capabilities to solve real problems and become experts in this area.

These successful results of the research have led to establishment of a theoretical foundation to address one of the key challenges in primary care operations. It has enabled us to study primary care systems adopting advanced technology, and opened up a new direction devoted to healthcare systems research. It has provided healthcare professionals and managers with quantitative tools and principles for operation management of healthcare delivery systems. The methodology is also be transferable to study other engineering disciplines, such as production systems, supply chains, communication and information networks, as well as logistic and service systems.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2020
Modified by: Jingshan Li
